intro: Galium pusillum subsp. brockmannii, commonly known as Brockmann's bedstraw, is a low-growing perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces tiny white to pale yellow flowers in clusters, typically blooming from late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of native plant communities in its habitat.
